questions.text: A 7-year-old male child was brought in the OPD due to the findings as shown in the image below. Which of the following occurs with the condition pictured in the given Image

options.label: A
options.text: The steepest meridian of the cornea is adjacent to this lesion

options.label: B
options.text: These are benign with no malignant potential

options.label: D
options.text: Patients may also have congenital cardiac defects

questions.correct_answer: B. These are benign with no malignant potential
questions.explanation:
Solution:

These are benign with no malignant potential Limbal dermoid are well-circumscribed, white–pale yellow, round lesions that are choristomas (heterotopic congenital lesions that result from normal tissue residing in an abnormal location). They have no malignant potential.

Highyeild:

Congenital tumors Dermoids. These are common congenital tumors that usually occur at the limbus. They appear as solid white masses, firmly fixed to the cornea . The Dermoid consists of collagenous connective tissue, sebaceous glands, and hair, lined by epidermoid epithelium . Treatment is simple excision. Lipodermoid. It is a congenital tumor, usually found at the limbus or outer canthus. It appears as a soft, yellowish-white, movable Lipodermoid subconjunctival mass. It consists of fatty tissue and the surrounding dermis-like connective tissue, hence the name lipodermoid. Sometimes, the peribulbar dermoid or lipodermoids may be associated with accessory auricles and other congenital defects ( Goldenhar's syndrome). Both limbal dermoid and dermal lipomas are more common in children with a congenital developmental anomaly known as Goldenharsyndrome (oculoauriculovertebral dysplasia) . This Syndrome affects structures derived from the first branchial arch leading to preauricular tags, deformities of the external ear, and vertebral anomalies . Colobomas of the lids and iris and Duane retraction syndrome are other associated ocular abnormalities.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The flattest meridian of the cornea is adjacent to the dermoid. Option: C They tend to grow as the child grows, but usually very slowly. Option: D. They can be associated with Goldenhar syndrome, a triad of peribulbar dermoid, facial anomalies, and skeletal anomalies. Goldenhar syndrome is a rare congenital condition characterized by abnormal development of the eye, ear, and spine . Also known as ocular-auricula-vertebral spectrum or OAV

Extraedge:

Classification Non-pigmented tumors Congenital : Dermoid and lipodermoid ( choristomas ). Benign : Simple granuloma, papilloma, adenoma, fibroma and angiomas. Premalignant : Intraepithelial epithelioma (Bowen's disease). Malignant : Epithelioma or squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma. Pigmented tumors Benign : Naevi or congenital moles. Precancerous melanosis : Superficial spreading melanoma and lentigo maligna (Hutchinson's freckle). Malignant : Primary melanoma (malignant melanoma).

questions.text: A 20-year-old female came in with dry eyes, itchiness, and watering. On examination, you notice the shortening of the inferior fornices and adhesion between the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva. A biopsy of the involved mucous membrane showed linear antibodies. Which of the following statements are correct regarding this patient:

options.label: A
options.text: Have immunoglobulins bound to the conjunctival basement membrane

options.label: B
options.text: May have increased numbers of goblet cells

options.label: C
options.text: Benefit from limbal stem cell transplants

questions.correct_answer: A. Have immunoglobulins bound to the conjunctival basement membrane
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Have immunoglobulins bound to the conjunctival basement membrane The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Mucous membrane pemphigoid (MMP), also known as ocular cicatricial pemphigoid (OCP). Mucous membrane pemphigoid (MMP), also known as ocular cicatricial pemphigoid (OCP), comprises a group of chronic autoimmune mucocutaneous blistering diseases. Diagnosis is principally clinical, but a biopsy of the involved mucous membrane often shows supportive changes ( linear antibody and complement BMZ deposition). Fine lines of subconjunctival fibrosis and shortening of the inferior fornices is a typical features of ocular cicatricial pemphigoid.

Highyeild:

Cicatricial pemphigoid is a chronic disease that affects mucosal surfaces typically in the elderly population.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Ocular cicatricial pemphigoid is usually bilateral (but may be very asymmetric) and associated with chronic conjunctivitis. This leads to subconjunctival fibrosis and a drop in the number of goblet cells. Subconjunctival fibrosis also may lead to obstruction of the ducts of the lacrimal and accessory lacrimal glands. Option: C. Monitoring should include the measurement of fornical depth and noting the position of adhesions. Systemic treatment is the mainstay of management. Any detectable inflammatory activity should be suppressed. Dapsone (diamino diphenyl sulfone) is a useful first-line treatment in patients with mild–moderate disease. Approximately 70% of patients respond favorably. Mucous membrane autografting or amniotic membrane transplantation can be done for conjunctival resurfacing and fornical restoration. Option D: Scleritis is not associated with this disease process. Progression usually results in symblepharon, foreshortening of the fornices, and ankyloblepharon. Keratinization of the conjunctival epithelium, as well as corneal neovascularization and scarring, are characteristic of end-stage ocular cicatricial pemphigoid.

Extraedge:

Immunoglobulins at the level of the basement membrane can be seen with immunofluorescent stains.

questions.text: A 24-year-old college student presents with the complaint of a localized area of redness in his right eye near the caruncle. The exam finding is shown in the given Image. He reports that he has had similar previous lesions that have resolved spontaneously. What would the lesion most likely show on the histopathological exam?

options.label: A
options.text: Spindle-shaped atypical cells with dark nuclei

questions.correct_answer: B. Acanthotic epithelium over fibrovascular cores
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acanthotic epithelium over fibrovascular cores The given Image shows a conjunctival papilloma. In children and young adults, lesions may be multiple and are usually found on the palpebral conjunctiva. They are of viral origin, and spontaneous resolution is common. These lesions contrast with noninfectious papillomas, which occur in older adults and are almost always single in occurrence, often at the limbus. Atypical cells with dark nuclei may be found histopathologically.

Highyeild:

Small caliber vascular channels in a collagenase stroma are found in pyogenic granuloma, and lined nonkeratinizing stratified squamous epithelia are found in epithelial inclusion cysts.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Spindle-shaped atypical cells with dark nuclei: Incorrect Option C. Round cells with clear cytoplasm: Incorrect Option D. Lined nonkeratinizing stratified squamous epithelium: Incorrect

Extraedge:

Classification Non-pigmented tumors Congenital : Dermoid and lipodermoid ( choristomas ). Benign : Simple granuloma, papilloma, adenoma, fibroma, and angiomas. Premalignant : Intraepithelial epithelioma (Bowen's disease). Malignant : Epithelioma or squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma. Pigmented tumors Benign : Naevi or congenital moles. Precancerous melanosis : Superficial spreading melanoma and lentigo maligna (Hutchinson's freckle). Malignant : Primary melanoma (malignant melanoma).

questions.text: A conjunctival pathology is shown in the image below. Which one of the following options is not a cause of a secondary acquired form of the disease process shown in this Image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scleritis Causes of secondary-acquired conjunctival melanosis include Addison disease, radiation, and pregnancy. Black conjunctival adrenochrome deposits result from the oxidative by-products of epinephrine compounds.

Highyeild:

Systemic disorders and drugs are linked rarely with acquired conjunctival pigmentation but include: Addison’s disease (adrenal gland deficiency) alkaptonuria (congenital enzyme deficiency) drugs (chlorpromazine, topical epinephrine, etc)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Pregnancy can cause Option: B . Topical epinephrine drops: Black conjunctival adrenochrome deposits result from the oxidative by-products of epinephrine compounds. Option: C . Addison disease: Causes of secondary-acquired conjunctival melanosis include Addison disease, radiation, and pregnancy.

questions.text: Match the following Images depicting different disease processes of the conjunctiva to their respective features. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A Conjunctival malignant melanoma (option A ) is a pigmented elevated lesion that enlarges progressively with time. It occurs most commonly on the bulbar conjunctiva. These tumors are very vascular, and dilated vessels may be seen feeding the tumor. The prognosis is generally better than cutaneous melanomas. A systemic metastatic workup is necessary to direct treatment. Conjunctival melanomas can arise de novo (30%), from nevi (40%), or primary acquired melanosis (30%).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. A conjunctival nevus (Image B) is a flat or slightly elevated pigmented lesion of the bulbar conjunctiva. It may have epithelial inclusion cysts within its substance. These lesions can grow or enlarge during adolescence or pregnancy. Suspicious lesions should be biopsied to rule out melanoma. Option: C . Racial or ocular melanosis (Image C) is found most commonly in pigmented individuals and represents benign collections of melanin in the conjunctiva. It appears as a perilimbal dusting of light brown pigment. No malignant potential exists. Option: D. Primary-acquired melanosis (Image D) is a unilateral condition found in middle-aged people. These multiple, superficial, flat patches of pigmentation develop into malignant melanoma in 20% to 30% of these patients. Excisional biopsy should be performed on any suspicious nodular lesions.

questions.text: A 38-year-old businesswoman presented with redness and tearing. The exam finding is shown in the image below. The medical history is significant for hypertension; well-controlled in medical management. Which one of the following regarding the condition shown in the given Image is true?

options.label: B
options.text: Resection of the adjacent conjunctiva may be indicated

options.label: C
options.text: Treatment with a silver nitrate stick is beneficial

options.label: D
options.text: A Fox shield at bedtime is helpful

questions.correct_answer: B. Resection of the adjacent conjunctiva may be indicated
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Resection of the adjacent conjunctiva may be indicated The Image shows superior limbal hyperemia and mild keratitis consistent with superior limbal keratoconjunctivitis . Superior palpebral conjunctival papillary reaction, micropannus, and filaments may also be present.

Highyeild:

Rose bengal or lissamine green is a vital dye that highlights the affected conjunctiva.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The reduced corneal sensation is a common finding in herpetic disease and is not associated with superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis. Option: C. Treatment may include 5% to 1.0% silver nitrate solution (not a silver nitrate stick), pressure patching, mechanical scraping, conjunctival resection, or bandage contact lenses. Thyroid dysfunction must be considered and thyroid function tests performed. Thyroid abnormalities have been associated with superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis. Option D: Floppy eyelid syndrome , which is most common in obese individuals and is characterized by easy eversion of superior tarsus and papillary response, responds well to sleeping with a protective eye shield. A Fox shield is a rigid eye shield that vaults the eye when a penetrating ocular injury is present or suspected.

Extraedge:

Treatment may include 5% to 1.0% silver nitrate solution (not a silver nitrate stick), pressure patching, mechanical scraping, conjunctival resection, or bandage contact lenses.

questions.text: What is the most common malignant epithelial tumor of the conjunctiva?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Squamous cell carcinoma Basal cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the eyelid skin, but squamous cell carcinoma is the most frequently occurring malignancy of the conjunctiva. Squamous papillomas are benign lesions that can, on rare occasions, undergo malignant transformation.

Highyeild:

Squamous cell carcinoma (epithelioma) This occurs where one kind of epithelium passes into another; therefore, in the conjunctiva, it occurs chiefly at the limbus . Squamous cell carcinoma of the conjunctiva

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Basal Cell Carcinoma : It may invade the conjunctiva from the lids or may arise pari-passu from the plica semilunaris or caruncle. Though it responds very favorably to radiotherapy, the complete surgical excision, if possible, should be preferred to avoid complications of radiotherapy. Option: C. Malignant melanoma: Malignant melanoma (primary melanoma). Malignant melanoma of the conjunctiva mostly arises de-novo, usually near the limbus, or rarely, it may occur due to malignant change in pre-existing nevus. The condition usually occurs in elderly patients. Option: D. Squamous papilloma: Squamous papillomas are benign lesions that can, on rare occasions, undergo malignant transformation.

Extraedge:

Papillomata in old people often take on malignant proliferation . Bowen intraepithelial epithelioma or carcinoma in situ is also seen. Squamous cell carcinoma spreads over the surface and into the fornices, rarely penetrating the globe. They have the structural characteristics of such growth elsewhere. They must be removed as freely as possible, the base being cauterized by diathermy or treated with cryotherapy; diagnosis should be microscopically confirmed . On the slightest sign of recurrence with invasive squamous cell carcinoma, the eye must be excised ; if recurrence takes place, the orbit must be exenterated and radiation therapy is given.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient from Rajasthan came in with the lesion shown in the Image below, irritation, and foreign body sensation. He reports that his father and uncle also have suffered from similar lesions but never sought consultation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pterygium The given case history and findings point toward the diagnosis of Pterygium . The Image shows the pterygium showing the cap, head, body, and Stocker line (arrow) . A pterygium (plural pterygia) is a triangular fibrovascular subepithelial ingrowth of degenerative bulbar conjunctival tissue over the limbus onto the cornea . It typically develops in patients who have been living in sunny countries and, as with pinguecula, may represent a response to ultraviolet exposure and other factors such as chronic surface dryness. The condition tends to run in families.

Highyeild:

Pterygium Pterygium (meaning ‘a wing’) is a triangular encroachment of the vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area. Etiopathogenesis: It is a degenerative condition of the subconjunctival tissue which proliferates as a vascularized granulation tissue encroaching upon the cornea and destroying the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Symblepharon formation refers to adhesion between the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva and is seen in this disease. Option: B. Ankyloblepharon is an adhesion at the outer canthus between the upper and lower lids.It may occur in association with ocular cicatricial pemphigoid . Option: C. A pinguecula is an innocuous but extremely common asymptomatic elastotic degeneration of the conjunctival stroma. It is usually found in elderly people, especially those who are exposed to strong sunlight, dust, and wind.

Extraedge:

Pterygium is characterized by an opacity lying deeply in the neighboring part of the cornea in front of its blunt apex. The formation of dense fibrous tissue leads to the development of considerable corneal astigmatism. The Condition is common in dry sunny climates with sandy soils as in parts of Australia, South Africa, Texas, the Middle East, and South and Southeast Asia . Ultraviolet light is probably an aetiological factor

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient from Rajasthan came in with the rapid onset of the lesion shown in the Image below, irritation, and foreign body sensation. He reports that his father and uncle also have suffered from similar lesions but never sought consultation. Which of the following statements is not true about this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The lesion is made up of three parts

options.label: B
options.text: Patients who wear contact lenses may develop symptoms earlier

options.label: D
options.text: Treatment is usually unnecessary because growth is absent

questions.correct_answer: D. Treatment is usually unnecessary because growth is absent
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Treatment is usually unnecessary because growth is absent The given case history and findings point toward the diagnosis of Pterygium. The Image shows the pterygium showing the cap, head, body, and Stocker line (arrow). A pterygium (plural pterygia) is a triangular fibrovascular subepithelial ingrowth of degenerative bulbar conjunctival tissue over the limbus onto the cornea. It typically develops in patients who have been living in sunny countries and, as with pinguecula, may represent a response to ultraviolet exposure and other factors such as chronic surface dryness. The condition tends to run in families. Patients who present with a history of recent enlargement are more likely to require early excision for subsequent aggressive growth. Aggressive growth or an atypical appearance should prompt an excision biopsy . Treatment is usually unnecessary in the case of pinguecula because growth is absent or very slow.

Highyeild:

Treatment of Pterygium Medical treatment of not much use. Tear substitutes may be used in patients with small regressive pterygium for dry eye symptoms. Topical steroids may be required for associated inflammation. Protection from ultraviolet rays with sunglasses decreases the growth stimulus. Surgical excision is the only satisfactory treatment that may be indicated for Cosmetic disfigurement. Visual impairment due to significant regular or irregular astigmatism. Continued progression threatening to encroach onto the pupillary area (once the pterygium has encroached pupillary area, wait till it crosses on the other side). Diplopia due to interference in ocular movements.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. A pterygium is made up of three parts: a cap' (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge), a head, and a body as seen in the given figure. Option: B. Patients who wear contact lenses may develop symptoms of irritation at an earlier stage due to edge lift. Lesions may interfere with vision by obscuring the visual axis or inducing astigmatism. Option: C. A pterygium is histologically similar to a pinguecula and shows elastotic degenerative changes in vascularized subepithelial stromal collagen. In contrast to pinguecula , pterygia encroaches onto the cornea, invading the Bowman layer .

Extraedge:

Recurrence of the pterygium after surgical excision is the main problem (30- 50%). However, it can be reduced by any of the following measures: Surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal autograft (CLAU) taken from the same eye or other eye is presently the preferred technique. Surgical excision with amniotic membrane graft and mitomycin-C (MMC) (0.02%) application may be required in recurrent pterygium or when dealing with a very large pterygium. Surgical excision with lamellar keratectomy and lamellar keratoplasty may be required in deeply infiltrating recurrent recalcitrant pterygia. Old methods to prevent recurrence (not used now) included transplantation of pterygium in the lower fornix (McRaynold's operation) and postoperative use of beta irradiations.

questions.text: A 67-year-old female came in with tearing, blurring of vision, itchiness, and foreign body sensation. The exam showed bilateral eye involvement with lesions as seen in the image below. What is true about this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Considerable corneal astigmatism may be seen in these patients.

options.label: B
options.text: It is formed due to inspissated mucus in Henle glands

options.label: C
options.text: It appears with adhesions to the adjacent lid and tissue anchoring the lesion to the underlying surface.

options.label: D
options.text: It is best left alone if it is progressing towards the pupillary area

questions.correct_answer: A. Considerable corneal astigmatism may be seen in these patients.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Considerable corneal astigmatism may be seen in these patients. The Image shows the pterygium presenting as a wing-shaped extension of the conjunctiva over the cornea. A pterygium (plural pterygia) is a triangular fibrovascular subepithelial ingrowth of degenerative bulbar conjunctival tissue over the limbus onto the cornea. It typically develops in patients who have been living in sunny countries and, as with pinguecula, may represent a response to ultraviolet exposure and other factors such as chronic surface dryness. It is characterized by an opacity lying deeply in the neighboring part of the cornea in front of its blunt apex. The lesion thus appears as thick vascularized conjunctiva growing onto the cornea from the canthus and is loosely adherent in its whole length to the sclera, the area of adherence being always smaller than its breadth so that there are folds at the upper and lower borders. Formation of dense fibrous tissue leads to the development of considerable corneal astigmatism.

Highyeild:

Pterygium Pterygium (meaning ‘a wing’) is a triangular encroachment of the vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area. Etiopathogenesis: It is a degenerative condition of the subconjunctival tissue which proliferates as a vascularized granulation tissue encroaching upon the cornea and destroying the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane. It is characterized by an opacity lying deeply in the neighboring part of the cornea in front of its blunt apex. Formation of dense fibrous tissue leads to the development of considerable corneal astigmatism. The Condition is common in dry sunny climates with sandy soils as in parts of Australia, South Africa, Texas, the Middle East, and South and Southeast Asia . Ultraviolet light is probably an aetiological factor.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Concretions (lithiasis ) are formed due to the accumulation of epithelial cells and inspissated mucus in depressions called Henle glands. These occur as minute, hard, yellow spots in the palpebral conjunctiva. Option: C. Pseudopterygium , which is a pterygium-like lesion, is induced by cicatrizing conjunctival inflammatory overgrowth. It appears with adhesions to the adjacent lid and scar tissue anchoring the lesion to the underlying surface, unlike a true pterygium beneath which a probe can be passed at the edges. Option: D. A pterygium is best left alone unless it is progressing towards the pupillary area, causes excessive astigmatism, a restriction of ocular motility, or is disfiguring. It cannot be removed without leaving a scar unless a lamellar corneal graft replaces it.

Extraedge:

Parts of a fully-developed pterygium are as follows: Head: Apical part present on the cornea, N67-year-oldicted part present in the limbal area, and Body: Sciera! part, extending between the limbus and the canthus. Cap: Semilunar whitish infiltrate present just in front of the head. Types . : Based on the extent, pterygium has been described of three types: Type I pterygium extends less than 2 mm onto the cornea. Type 2 pterygium involves up to 4 mm of the cornea. Type 3 pterygium encroaches onto more than 4 mm of the cornea and involves the visual axis. Depending upon the progression, it may be progressive or regressive pterygium . Progressive pterygium is thick, fleshy, and vascular with a few whitish infiltrates in the cornea, in front of the head of the pterygium known as Fuchs spots or islets of Vogt also called cap of pterygium. Regressive pterygium is thin, atrophic, and attenuated with very little vascularity. There is no cap, but deposition of iron (Stocker's line) may be seen sometimes, just anterior to the head of the pterygium. Ultimately, it becomes membranous but never disappears.

questions.text: A 71-year-old female recently underwent cataract surgery. On follow up, you notice the following findings shown in the Image. She reports presence of gritty sensation and foreign body sensation which she thought must have been due to the lens placement and thus did not seek consultation. She reported that she had a similar albeit smaller lesion in her eyes before the surgery. Which of the following is not true about appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgical therapy is required in all of these cases.

options.label: B
options.text: Autoconjunctival graft should be done to avoid complications

options.label: C
options.text: Removal of the lesion is affected by seizing the neck near the corneal margin

options.label: D
options.text: The patient should be advised to wear sunglasses

questions.correct_answer: A. Surgical therapy is required in all of these cases.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Surgical therapy is required in all of these cases. The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Pterygium. The Image shows the pterygium presenting as a wing-shaped extension of the conjunctiva over the cornea. Recurrence of pterygium after surgery with coincidental arcus senilis can be seen here. A pterygium (plural pterygia) is a triangular fibrovascular subepithelial ingrowth of degenerative bulbar conjunctival tissue over the limbus onto the cornea. It typically develops in patients who have been living in sunny countries and, as with pinguecula, may represent a response to ultraviolet exposure and to other factors such as chronic surface dryness. A pterygium is best left alone unless it is progressing towards the pupillary area , causes excessive astigmatism, a restriction of ocular motility, or is disfiguring. It cannot be removed without leaving a scar unless a lamellar corneal graft replaces it.

Highyeild:

Treatment of Pterygium Medical treatment of not much use. Tear substitutes may be used in patients with small regressive pterygium for dry eye symptoms. Topical steroids may be required for associated inflammation. Protection from ultraviolet rays with sunglasses decreases the growth stimulus. Surgical excision is the only satisfactory treatment that may be indicated for Cosmetic disfigurement. Visual impairment due to significant regular or irregular astigmatism. Continued progression threatening to encroach onto the pupillary area (once the pterygium has encroached pupillary area, wait till it crosses on the other side). Diplopia due to interference in ocular movements.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. An effective method of preventing recurrences is to perform an auto conjunctival graft (taking a piece of limbal conjunctival tissue from the same or the other eye) or an amniotic membrane graft and suturing it at the limbus to cover the defect produced by excising the pterygium. Option: C. Removal of the pterygium is affected by seizing the neck near the corneal margin with fixation forceps, raising it, and shaving or dissecting it from the cornea, starting from the apex. Care must be taken not to go too deep. Option: D. The patient should be advised to wear sunglasses to reduce ultraviolet exposure.

Extraedge:

Recurrence of the pterygium after surgical excision is the main problem (30- 50%). However, it can be reduced by any of the following measures: Surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal autograft (CLAU) taken from the same eye or other eye is presently the preferred technique. Surgical excision with amniotic membrane graft and mitomycin-C (MMC) (0.02%) application may be required in recurrent pterygium or when dealing with a very large pterygium. Surgical excision with lamellar keratectomy and lamellar keratoplasty may be required in deeply infiltrating recurrent recalcitrant pterygia. Old methods to prevent recurrence (not used now) included transplantation of pterygium in the lower fornix (McRaynold's operation) and postoperative use of beta irradiations.

questions.text: Match the below ocular findings to their respective disease processes/ conditions. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-f, 2-e, 3-c. Concretions: These occur as minute, hard, yellow spots in the palpebral conjunctiva. Concretions are formed due to the accumulation of epithelial cells and inspissated mucus in depressions called Henle glands. Hemorrhagic lymphangiectasia : It is characterized by strings of cystic or sausage-shaped clear-walled channels, which may become filled with blood. Pseudopterygium: Pseudopterygium , which is in fact a pterygium-like lesion, is induced by cicatrizing conjunctival inflammatory overgrowth produced by trauma, thermochemical burn or chronic conjunctivitis. Pseudopterygium appears similar clinically but is caused by a band of conjunctiva adhering to an area of the compromised cornea at its apex. Pterygium: Pterygium (meaning ‘a wing’) is a triangular encroachment of the vascularized granulation tissue cered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area. Subconjunctival hemorrhage: The hemorrhage is usually asymptomatic but a momentary sharp pain or a snapping or popping sensation is sometimes felt. Coughing, sneezing, and vomiting are common precipitants. In younger people contact lens wear is a common association and in older individuals, systemic vascular disease (hypertension) is prevalent. Conjunctivochalasis: Conjunctivochalasis usually appears as a fold of redundant conjunctiva interposed between the globe and lower eyelid, protruding over the lid margin.

Highyeild:

Pterygium Pterygium (meaning ‘a wing’) is a triangular encroachment of the vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area. Etiopathogenesis: It is a degenerative condition of the subconjunctival tissue which proliferates as a vascularized granulation tissue encroaching upon the cornea and destroying the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane. It is characterized by an opacity lying deeply in the neighboring part of the cornea in front of its blunt apex. Formation of dense fibrous tissue leads to the development of considerable corneal astigmatism. The Condition is common in dry sunny climates with sandy soils as in parts of Australia, South Africa, Texas, the Middle East, and South and SoutheastAsia . Ultraviolet light is probably an aetiological factor.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child presents with the following lesion containing fibrofatty tissue. This patient is most likely to have:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adenomatous Polyposis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Limbal dermoid. Limbal dermoid is a characteristic feature of Gardner syndrome (GS). It is found in approximately 40 percent of patients with GS. Colobomas of the lids and iris and Duane retraction syndrome are other associated ocular abnormalities.

Highyeild:

GS is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by precancerous intestinal polyposis and subsequent adenocarcinoma of the gastrointestinal tract. Cutaneous manifestations include epidermoid cysts, osteomas, desmoids, and fibrous tumors . A mutation in the adenomatous polyposis coli ( APC) gene, a tumor suppressor gene , is responsible for the disease. Most patients develop colon carcinoma by the 2nd or 3rd decade . Therefore, prophylactic colectomy is warranted.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Pheochromocytomas are found in multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes IIa and IIb. Option: C. Tram track calcifications are found in Sturge- Weber syndrome. Option: D. Peg-shaped teeth are found in multiple syndromes including ectodermal dysplasia.

Extraedge:

Classification of Conjunctival tumors Non-pigmented tumours Congenital : Dermoid and lipodermoid ( choristomas ). Benign : Simple granuloma, papilloma, adenoma, fibroma, and angiomas. Premalignant : Intraepithelial epithelioma (Bowen's disease). Malignant : Epithelioma or squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma. Pigmented tumours Benign : Naevi or congenital moles. Precancerous melanosis : Superficial spreading melanoma and lentigo maligna (Hutchinson's freckle). Malignant : Primary melanoma (malignant melanoma).

questions.text: Match the below terms with the respective disease processes. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a-3, b-1, c-2, d-4. Squamous cell carcinoma: This occurs where one kind of epithelium passes into another; therefore, in the conjunctiva, it occurs chiefly at the limbus. Bowen intraepithelial epithelioma or carcinoma in situ is also seen. Conjunctival lymphoma: Conjunctival lymphoma occurs on the bulbar conjunctiva or in the fornix. They are typically described as painless, slow-growing, salmon-coloured, i.e. light pinkish, mildly elevated, homogeneous lesions which can sometimes have small, round aggregations that look like fish eggs. Conjunctival pyogenic granuloma: An infected polypoid or sessile granuloma develops after secondary bacterial infection following pterygium or squint surgery. Papillomata: These occur at the inner canthus, in the fornices or at the limbus. They may become malignant and should be removed.

Highyeild:

Classification of Conjunctival tumors Non-pigmented tumours Congenital : Dermoid and lipodermoid ( choristomas ). Benign : Simple granuloma, papilloma, adenoma, fibroma, and angiomas. Premalignant : Intraepithelial epithelioma (Bowen's disease). Malignant : Epithelioma or squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma. Pigmented tumours Benign : Naevi or congenital moles. Precancerous melanosis : Superficial spreading melanoma and lentigo maligna (Hutchinson's freckle). Malignant : Primary melanoma (malignant melanoma).

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV positive male presented with a conjunctival nodular lesion with hemorrhagic features. It is bluish red in color. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Kaposi sarcoma The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Kaposi sarcoma. This specific type of tumour is seen in patients suffering from the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) due to infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). The lesion may also affect the skin of the eyelids and face. The tumour is highly vascular, with a bluish red colour, and presents as an elevated nodule somewhat resembling a subconjunctival haemorrhage.

Highyeild:

Kaposi sarcoma This specific type of tumour is seen in patients suffering from the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) due to infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) . It affects the skin or any organ and is common in southern Mediterranean regions, Eastern Europe and Africa. If a conjunctival lesion is present, there is a high association with AIDS and eye involvement can be the first manifestation . The lesion may also affect the skin of the eyelids and face. The tumour is highly vascular, with a bluish-red color, and presents as an elevated nodule somewhat resembling a subconjunctival hemorrhage. The lesion is malignant and its treatment is palliative with radiotherapy .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A.Subconjunctival hemorrhage: The hemorrhage is usually asymptomatic but a momentary sharp pain or a snapping or popping sensation is sometimes felt. Coughing, sneezing, and vomiting are common precipitants. In younger people contact lens wear is a common association and in older individuals, systemic vascular disease (hypertension) is prevalent. Option: B. Hemorrhagic lymphangiectasia: It is characterized by strings of cystic or sausage-shaped clear-walled channels, which may become filled with blood Option: D. Conjunctival lymphoma Conjunctival lymphoma occurs on the bulbar conjunctiva or in the fornix. They are typically described as painless, slow-growing, salmon-colored, i.e. light pinkish, mildly elevated, homogeneous lesions which can sometimes have small, round aggregations that look like fish eggs.

Extraedge:

Kaposi sarcoma This specific type of tumour is seen in patients suffering from the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) due to infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) . It affects the skin or any organ and is common in southern Mediterranean regions, Eastern Europe and Africa. If a conjunctival lesion is present, there is a high association with AIDS and eye involvement can be the first manifestation . The lesion may also affect the skin of the eyelids and face. The tumour is highly vascular, with a bluish-red color, and presents as an elevated nodule somewhat resembling a subconjunctival hemorrhage. The lesion is malignant and its treatment is palliative with radiotherapy .

questions.text: Match the following statements with the respective pigmented tumors. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a-1, b-4, c-2, d-3. A. Congenital moles: They are grey, gelatinous, or pigmented nodules situated by preference at the limbus or near the plica semilunaris. They have the same structure as in the skin— groups, often alveolar, of nevus cells' in close connection with the epithelium. B. Kaposi sarcoma: The tumour is highly vascular, with a bluish-red color, and presents as an elevated nodule somewhat resembling a subconjunctival hemorrhage. The lesion is malignant and its treatment is palliative with radiotherapy. C. Bowen intraepithelial epithelioma: Removal with the base being cauterized by diathermy or treated with cryotherapy D. Simple granulomata: They are common in empty sockets after excision and at the site of chalazia which have been insufficiently scraped.

Highyeild:

Kaposi sarcoma This specific type of tumour is seen in patients suffering from the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) due to infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) . It affects the skin or any organ and is common in southern Mediterranean regions, Eastern Europe and Africa. If a conjunctival lesion is present, there is a high association with AIDS and eye involvement can be the first manifestation . The lesion may also affect the skin of the eyelids and face. The tumour is highly vascular, with a bluish-red color, and presents as an elevated nodule somewhat resembling a subconjunctival hemorrhage. The lesion is malignant and its treatment is palliative with radiotherapy .

questions.text: A 79-year-old female presents with dry eyes, foreign body sensation, and tearing. The exam finding is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Conjunctivochalasis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Conjunctivochalasis. This is a condition that is seen in elderly people with laxity of the conjunctiva leading to folds usually visibly heaped on the lid margin. It can be asymptomatic or produce ocular discomfort due to dry eye and a foreign body sensation with tearing.

Highyeild:

Conjunctivochalasis This is a condition that is seen in elderly people with laxity of the conjunctiva leading to folds usually visibly heaped on the lid margin . It can be asymptomatic or produce ocular discomfort due to ‘dry eye and a foreign body sensation with tearing .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Symblepharon is an adhesion between the bulbar and palpebral conjunctivae and occurs due to any condition which makes opposing surfaces raw and inflamed, allowing cicatrization and fibrosis. Option: C. Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is a conditi79-year-oldy deficiency of the aqueous component of tears, i.e. the lacrimal secretion. It is a general, systemic, and autoimmune disturbance usually occurring in women after menopause and often associated with rheumatoid arthritis. Option: D. Simple granulomas are common in empty sockets after excision and at the site of chalazia which have been insufficiently scraped.

Extraedge:

Symptomatic relief can be provided by prescribing artificial tears four to six times a day , modifying the frequency as necessary. Sometimes, surgical excision of redundant folds(conjunctivoplasty) is required.

questions.text: A 69-year-old male presents with the following ocular finding. He reported that it has been developing for a few months but he wasn’t able to seek consultation due to the occurrence of coronavirus pandemic. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Malignant melanoma The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Malignant melanoma. It occurs typically at the limbus, is usually pigmented, and occurs mostly in the elderly . It spreads over the surface of the globe but rarely penetrates it; recurrences and metastases occur elsewhere in the body.

Highyeild:

Pigmented tumours. Benign: Naevi or congenital moles. Precancerous melanosis: Superficial spreading melanoma and lentigo maligna (Hutchinson's freckle). Malignant: Primary melanoma (malignant melanoma) Malignant melanoma is rare. It occurs typically at the limbus , is usually pigmented, and occurs mostly in the elderly . It spreads over the surface of the globe but rarely penetrates it; recurrences and metastases occur elsewhere in the body. The neoplasm may be alveolar(derived from naevi) or round- or spindle-celled . The treatment is by excision of the globe or exenteration of the orbit .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Precancerous melanosis is a diffusely spreading pigmentation of the conjunctiva, occurring rarely in elderly people, which may also involve the skin of the lids and cheek. Option: B. Naevi or congenital moles are seen very commonly. They are grey, gelatinous, or pigmented nodules situated by preference at the limbus or near the plica semilunaris. Option: C. Bowen intraepithelial epithelioma or carcinoma in situ is seen with Squamous cell carcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma spreads over the surface and into the fornices, rarely penetrating the globe. They must be removed as freely as possible, the base being cauterized by diathermy or treated with cryotherapy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with a pimple like lesion which progressed into the lesion as shown in the image below. On exam, you notice it is extending from the inner canthus to the inside of the conjunctival margin. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Basal cell carcinoma The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Basal cell carcinoma (rodent ulcer). Basal cell carcinoma may invade the conjunctiva from the lids. It commences as a small pimple that ulcerates and if the scab is removed, it is found that the edges are raised, rolled, and indurated. The ulcer spreads very slowly , the epithelial growth extending under the skin in all directions and penetrating deeply. It shows a predilection for the lower lid inner canthus as seen in the given Image.

Highyeild:

Basal cell carcinoma. It may invade the conjunctiva from the lids or may arise pari-passu from the plica semilunaris or caruncle. Though it responds very favorably to radiotherapy, the complete surgical excision, if possible, should be preferred to avoid complications of radiotherapy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A Sometimes, an infected polypoid or sessile granuloma develops after secondary bacterial infection following pterygium or squint surgery. The lesion is surgically excised and diagnosis confirmed by histopathological examination. Option: B. Bowen intraepithelial epithelioma or carcinoma in situ is also seen. Squamous cell carcinoma spreads over the surface and into the fornices, rarely penetrating the globe. They must be removed as freely as possible, the base being cauterized by diathermy or treated with cryotherapy; diagnosis should be microscopically confirmed. Option: C. Papillomata: These occur at the inner canthus, in the fornices, or at the limbus . They may become malignant and should be removed.

Extraedge:

Classification of Conjunctival tumors Non-pigmented tumours Congenital : Dermoid and lipodermoid ( choristomas ). Benign : Simple granuloma, papilloma, adenoma, fibroma, and angiomas. Premalignant : Intraepithelial epithelioma (Bowen's disease). Malignant : Epithelioma or squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma. Pigmented tumours Benign : Naevi or congenital moles. Precancerous melanosis : Superficial spreading melanoma and lentigo maligna (Hutchinson's freckle). Malignant : Primary melanoma (malignant melanoma).
